title: 1041-D
statement: D. Glidertime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputA plane is flying at a constant height of $$$h$$$ meters above the ground surface. Let's consider that it is flying from the point $$$(-10^9, h)$$$ to the point $$$(10^9, h)$$$ parallel with $$$Ox$$$ axis.A glider is inside the plane, ready to start his flight at any moment (for the sake of simplicity let's consider that he may start only when the plane's coordinates are integers). After jumping from the plane, he will fly in the same direction as the plane, parallel to $$$Ox$$$ axis, covering a unit of distance every second. Naturally, he will also descend; thus his second coordinate will decrease by one unit every second.There are ascending air flows on certain segments, each such segment is characterized by two numbers $$$x_1$$$ and $$$x_2$$$ ($$$x_1 < x_2$$$) representing its endpoints. No two segments share any common points. When the glider is inside one of such segments, he doesn't descend, so his second coordinate stays the same each second. The glider still flies along $$$Ox$$$ axis, covering one unit of distance every second.If the glider jumps out at $$$1$$$, he will stop at $$$10$$$. Otherwise, if he jumps out at $$$2$$$, he will stop at $$$12$$$.Determine the maximum distance along $$$Ox$$$ axis from the point where the glider's flight starts to the point where his flight ends if the glider can choose any integer coordinate to jump from the plane and start his flight. After touching the ground the glider stops altogether, so he cannot glide through an ascending airflow segment if his second coordinate is $$$0$$$.InputThe first line contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$h$$$ $$$(1 \\le n \\le 2\\cdot10^{5}, 1 \\le h \\le 10^{9})$$$ — the number of ascending air flow segments and the altitude at which the plane is flying, respectively.Each of the next $$$n$$$ lines contains two integers $$$x_{i1}$$$ and $$$x_{i2}$$$ $$$(1 \\le x_{i1} < x_{i2} \\le 10^{9})$$$ — the endpoints of the $$$i$$$-th ascending air flow segment. No two segments intersect, and they are given in ascending order.OutputPrint one integer — the maximum distance along $$$Ox$$$ axis that the glider can fly from the point where he jumps off the plane to the point where he lands if he can start his flight at any integer coordinate.ExamplesInput3 42 57 910 11Output10Input5 105 711 1216 2025 2630 33Output18Input1 10000000001 1000000000Output1999999999NoteIn the first example if the glider can jump out at $$$(2, 4)$$$, then the landing point is $$$(12, 0)$$$, so the distance is $$$12-2 = 10$$$.In the second example the glider can fly from $$$(16,10)$$$ to $$$(34,0)$$$, and the distance is $$$34-16=18$$$.In the third example the glider can fly from $$$(-100,1000000000)$$$ to $$$(1999999899,0)$$$, so the distance is $$$1999999899-(-100)=1999999999$$$.

A plane is flying horizontally at a constant height of $h$ meters.  It is flying from the point $(-10^9, h)$ to the point $(10^9, h)$. A glider is inside the plane and can jump out at any integer coordinate along the plane's path.

After jumping, the glider flies in the same horizontal direction at a speed of 1 unit per second.  The glider also descends at a rate of 1 unit per second.

There are ascending air flows along certain segments of the plane's path. Each segment is defined by two integers, $x_1$ and $x_2$ ($x_1 < x_2$), representing the start and end points of the segment. No two segments overlap. While the glider is within an ascending air flow segment, he does not descend.

What is the maximum horizontal distance the glider can travel from its jump point to its landing point? The glider stops flying when it reaches the ground (second coordinate of 0).

A plane flies horizontally. At certain points along its path, there are air currents that prevent the plane from descending.  A person can jump from the plane at any integer point along its path and will fall at a rate of one unit per second.  The person can also fly horizontally at a rate of one unit per second.  What is the maximum horizontal distance the person can travel before landing on the ground?
